I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to India for the Chhattisgarh State Road Sector Project. The report also describes proposed 
technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Institutional  Strengthening  of  the  Chhattisgarh  Public  Works 
Department  (CGPWD),  and  if  the  Board  approves  the  proposed  loan,  I,  acting  under  the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA.1 
 
2.  The project will improve about 916 kilometers  (km) of state roads, in line with the 
Chhattisgarh  Road  Master  Plan,  2005–2016.  It  will  involve  upgrading  roads  to  two  lanes, 
strengthening culverts and bridges, and building new road sections and bridges. Consulting 
support will be provided to support implementation of civil works.2 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Under its India country partnership strategy, 2009–2012, the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) supports all levels of road sector development as a core infrastructure operation to 
facilitate sustainable economic growth.3 The project is consistent with the strategic objective set 
out in the country partnership strategy, which recognizes the limited network capacity and 
limited  operational  capacity  for  management  of  road  assets  and  road  safety  as  the  main 
challenges in the road transport sector in India; and recommends the expansion of support to 
the state road sector to ensure an inclusive approach to fill the gap between ADB’s financial 
support in the rural road sector and the Government of India’s National Highway Development 
Program. The project is included in ADB’s India country operations business plan, 2012–2014 
and was advanced for approval in 2012 because of the high level of project preparation and 
project readiness achieved.4 
 
4.  In India, road transport accounts for 68% of freight movement and 87% of passenger 
traffic. The national highways and the secondary system are unable to cope with the rapid traffic 
growth. In the road sector, freight traffic increased by about 12% and passenger traffic by about 
8% per year from 2000 to 2008 (footnote 3). The rapid growth in traffic has led to congestion, 
deterioration of roads, and increased transport costs. State roads, the secondary road system in 
India, link national highways with district headquarters and important towns. The secondary 
system comprises about 13% of the road network and carries about 40% of traffic. About half of 
the roads in the secondary system are estimated to be of poor riding quality. 
    
5.  Chhattisgarh is one of the underdeveloped states of India and was established on 1 
November 2000 through bifurcation from Madhya Pradesh state. Chhattisgarh is rich in mineral 
and coal deposits and is located in the east of central India. About 41% of its 21 million 
population live below the national poverty line. Since about 32% of its population is tribal and 
scheduled caste, and forests cover about 44% of its area of 135,194 square kilometers (km2), it 
is known as a tribal and forest state. 
 
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
2  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided TA to prepare the project. (ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to India 
for Capacity Development to Enhance Project Readiness and Results Monitoring for Transport Projects. Manila TA 
7252-IND). 
3  ADB. 2009. Country Partnership Strategy: India, 2009–2012. Manila. 
4  ADB. 2012. Country Operations Business Plan: India, 2012–2014. Manila.

2 
6.  Roads are the main mode of transportation in Chhattisgarh. National highways provide 
good east–west connections with neighboring states, and the main north–south connection 
within the state. However, state highways and major district roads in Chhattisgarh are mostly in 
poor condition, and are not usable in the monsoon season. This is especially true for roads in 
southern and northern Chhattisgarh, where most of the tribal people live. Many roads are only 
single or intermediate lane roads, which lack sufficient capacity to cope with the growing traffic. 
The total road length in Chhattisgarh is about 36,000 km, with road density less than 30 km per 
100 km2 against the national average of 100 km per 100 km2. Moreover, 80% of its existing road 
network  has  an  international  roughness  index  worse  than  4.  Thus,  Chhattisgarh  lacks  an 
adequate road network to support the required mobility between areas with natural resources, 
industrial centers, and economic development zones, and to provide better access to social 
amenities.  
 
7.  To improve state roads, in 2002–2003, the CGPWD prepared a 10-Year Master Plan for 
Road Sector Development for 2003 to 2012, which aims to (i) promote the development of six 
main road corridors, (ii) remove capacity bottlenecks from the network to better connect rural 
areas, and (iii) support socioeconomic development by improving road access and connectivity 
among growth centers. Based on the master plan, the government of Chhattisgarh (GOC) 
prepared  and  approved  a  priority  investment  program  for  the  improvement,  rehabilitation, 
strengthening, and widening of about 5,000 km of state roads at an estimated cost of about 
Rs105 billion. The master plan was updated in February 2006 using ADB’s TA for Preparing the 
Chhattisgarh State Roads Sector Development to identify road sector development needs for 
2005–2016.5 It recommended the development of 8,871 km of state highways and major district 
roads at a cost of Rs33 billion in 2004 prices. 
 
8.  To support improvement of the road network in Chhattisgarh, by implementing the road 
master plan, ADB provided a loan of $180 million6 in 2003 for improvement of 1,250 km of state 
roads in Chhattisgarh as well as TA to support reforms in the state roads sector. The project 
was successfully implemented and completed in July 2011 but it faced completion delays of 
about 2.5 years. These were mainly due to (i) initial delays caused by a lack of project readiness 
at the time of loan approval; and (ii) limited capacity for project management and project 
implementation in the CGPWD, which was at the time of loan approval being established as an 
independent  department  for  the  state  of  Chhattisgarh,  which  was  bifurcated  from  Madhya 
Pradesh only 3 years earlier. ADB provided capacity development for road sector management 
in Chhattisgarh through TA (footnotes 5), which supported (i) updating of the road master plan 
for 2005–2016; and (ii) establishing policies for planning and management in the CGPWD, 
which also helped to prepare this project. Therefore,  delays in project implementation  are 
expected to be avoided, as (i) project readiness is high, with the detailed design of all sample 
roads and the proposed non-sample roads completed; and (ii) the institutional capacity of 
CGPWD has been substantially strengthened. 
 
9.  The  roads  proposed  for  inclusion  under  the  project  have  been  selected  from  this 
updated road master plan for 2005–2016. The project will supplement ADB’s support in the rural 
road sector in Chhattisgarh by linking rural roads to the state and national highway network—
providing access for the rural population to markets, businesses, social services, and education. 
 
                                                
5  ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance to India for Preparing the Chhattisgarh State Roads Sector Development. Manila 
(TA 3995-IND). 
6  ADB. 2003. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to India for the 
Chhattisgarh State Roads Development Sector Project. Manila (Loan 2050-IND).

3 
10.  The project is prepared as a sector loan, as (i) the GOC has a sector development plan 
in place (the road master plan, 2005–2016); (ii) the CGPWD has sufficient institutional capacity 
to implement this sector development plan, as demonstrated by the successful completion of 
the previous loan; and (iii) appropriate policies for project preparation and project management 
to implement the sector development plan have been established. The two sample subprojects 
are (i) the Simga–Kurud road (SH-20, 110 km); and (ii) the Nandghat–Gidhori road (SH-10, 91 
km). These represent almost 25% of the project cost. The non-sample roads will be selected 
and approved in line with the process outlined in the project administration manual (PAM).7 
  
11.  As the sector assessment identified lack of road maintenance in the past as the key 
factor leading to the deteriorated status of many project roads, the main focus of institutional 
strengthening  by  the  capacity  development  TA  attached  to  the  proposed  loan  will  be  on 
improving maintenance management and road asset management. The budget available to the 
CGPWD for road maintenance was found to be sufficient. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The  envisaged  impact  of  the  project  is  improved  connectivity  in  Chhattisgarh.  The 
outcome of the project is an improved road transport system in Chhattisgarh. 
 
C.  Outputs 
13.  The outputs of the project will be about 916 km of reconstructed and rehabilitated state 
roads in 15 road sections; the sample projects comprise of 2 roads with a total length of 201 km, 
the proposed non-sample roads comprise of 13 roads with a total length of 715 km. Thus, after 
completion of this project, a total of 2,166 km out of the 8,871 km of state roads identified in the 
state road sector development plan (2005–2016) for priority improvement and widening will be 
completed with ADB financing.  
 
14.  The TA attached to the project will support improvement of the capacity of the CGPWD 
in procurement, contract management, and project management. Establishment of a road asset 
management  system  initially  for  the  roads  financed  by  ADB  will  be  supported  by  the  TA 
including procurement, customization and commissioning of the information technology system, 
collection of the baseline data, training of staff in the use of the road asset management system 
for planning of road maintenance activities, and training of staff in expanding the road asset 
management for use with all roads managed by CGPWD. 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans  
 
15.  The project is estimated to cost $428.1 million (Table 1). 
 
16.  The government has requested a loan of $300,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace 
period  of  5  years,  an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London 
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility,8 a commitment charge of 0.15% per year 
and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan and project agreements. The 
government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s 
LIBOR-based lending facility on the basis of these terms and conditions, and (ii) an undertaking

A.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The executing agency for the project will be the GOC acting through the CGPWD. A 
project implementation unit, established under the CGPWD with field offices at key locations, 
will be responsible for day-to-day project implementation and management and will assign 
additional staff to work on the project. One or two full-time project managers will be assigned for 
each  contract  package.  The  project  managers  will  be  delegated  adequate  technical  and 
administrative  authority  for  expeditious  project  implementation.  The  CGPWD  will  engage 
construction supervision consultants to act as the engineers for the construction contracts. 
 
21.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in 
the PAM (footnote 7).

22.  ADB  approved  advance  contracting  of  civil  works  in  February  2012. During  project 
preparation, the CGPWD’s procurement activities for the sample roads were well advanced. 
Based on this, the government requested retroactive financing for all project components. Up to 
20% of the loan proceeds will be eligible for retroactive financing, provided that expenditures are 
incurred on works, equipment, and consulting services for the project in accordance with agreed 
procedures  and  during  the  12  months  before  the  signing  of  the  loan  agreement.  The 
government  and  the  GOC  have  been  informed  that  approval  of  advance  contracting  and 
retroactive financing does not in any way commit ADB to finance the project. 
V.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
23.  Capacity  development  TA  for  $1,000,000  for  Institutional  Strengthening  of  the 
Chhattisgarh Public Works Department will support the institutional development initiatives of 
the GOC. The TA will assist and support the project implementation unit in improving project 
implementation,  designing  and  approving  additional  non-sample  projects,  enhancing  road 
safety, and ensuring the future operation and maintenance of the project roads through an 
improved road asset management system. The consultants will conduct district and statewide 
training and workshops as required.

6 
24.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources); and (ii) $500,000 by 
the Department for International Development of the United Kingdom to be administered by 
ADB.10 An international consulting firm will be recruited by ADB according to its Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Consultants will be asked to 
submit simplified technical proposals, and the selection will be in accordance with ADB’s quality- 
and cost-based selection method using a quality–cost ratio of 80:20. 
VI.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
25.  The project was prepared with the enhanced capacity of the CGPWD, which has been 
gained through the first loan and TA provided for capacity building. The CGPWD engaged 
detailed design consultants with its own funds to prepare detailed design for roads proposed for 
ADB  financing,  incorporating  ADB’s  requirements  of  economic,  social,  and  environmental 
studies into the consultants’ terms of reference. The GOC asked ADB for TA to conduct due 
diligence to ensure that the detailed design complies with ADB requirements. 
 
26.  The engineering design for the project roads was prepared to minimize land acquisition 
as well as social and environmental impacts. A road safety audit was performed as part of the 
detailed design and the recommendations were incorporated in the engineering design of the 
project. Advance actions have been taken to ensure that the construction can commence early. 
All of these measures have improved project readiness and will mitigate the risk of delay. 
 
27.  The selection criteria and approval process for non-sample roads is provided in the PAM 
(footnote 7). All non-sample roads must be technically feasible, economically and financially 
viable, and safeguard reports in compliance with the resettlement framework, environmental 
assessment and review framework, and the indigenous peoples planning framework must have 
been approved by ADB. The detailed design for the non-sample roads has been completed by 
GOC under its own funding and GOC asked ADB for TA to conduct due diligence to ensure that 
the design for the non-sample roads complies with ADB requirements. The due diligence for the 
non-sample roads is in an advance stage of preparation. 
B.  Economic and Financial 
28.  The economic evaluation of the project followed the standard practice of comparing life 
cycle road and user costs with and without the project, using the net present value with a 12% 
discount rate and economic internal rate of return (EIRR) as decision criteria. The highway 
development and management system was used in the analysis, which focused on transport 
cost  savings.  Value  added  from  better  transport  links  resulting  in  new  industries  and 
employment are not quantified in this analysis but are captured through benefits from generated 
traffic.

7 
29.  The EIRR for the sample roads evaluated is 19.8% for the Nandghat–Gidhori road (SH-
10, 91 km) and 21.0% for the Simga–Kurud road (SH-20, 110 km). Overall, both sample roads 
are very robust, with high EIRR, satisfying the economic efficiency criteria. The sensitivity of the 
EIRR for the sample project roads was analyzed with respect to changes in the benefit and cost 
streams. The following sensitivity test cases were examined: (i) construction costs increased by 
15%, (ii) time benefits reduced by 50%, (iii) benefits decreased by 15%, and (iv) a combination 
of (i) and (iii). The results show that the quantified economic benefits are robust to various 
sensitivity tests. All selected roads have an EIRR above 12% in all sensitivity tests.11 
 
30.  Financial sustainability. Incremental recurrent costs associated with the project are 
estimated  to  be  0.8%  of  the  current  maintenance  budget  of  Chhattisgarh  Public  Works 
Department  and  0.2%  of  the  overall  budget  on  an  annual  basis.  The  allocation  for  road 
maintenance was on average around Rs2,800 million until FY2010–11, and has been increased 
to Rs3,040 million in FY2011–12 and Rs5,675 million in FY2012–13. The budget allocation for 
road maintenance in FY2012–13 was assessed to fully meet the maintenance needs for the 
state roads network and the Government of Chhattisgarh is committed to maintain a similar 
level of budget for road maintenance works. Thus, it is reasonable to expect that funds will be 
available to meet the maintenance costs. 
C.  Governance 
31.  Institutional capacity. A team of individual consultants supplemented the CGPWD’s 
capacity  during  project  preparation.  The  CGPWD’s  capacity  for  implementation  will  be 
supported by the supervision consultant, who will also assist with the approval process for non-
sample roads. For long-term capacity strengthening, TA will be provided to make the CGPWD 
more effective in developing, operating, and maintaining state roads. 
 
32.  Financial management. The CGPWD has experience in implementing an ADB-funded 
project. It has satisfactory capacity for project financial accounting and sufficient knowledge of 
ADB’s  disbursement  procedures.  The  TA  will  support  the  introduction  of  a  computerized 
accounting  system  in  the  project  implementation  unit  and  strengthening  of  the  financial 
management system.  
 
33.  Procurement.  Goods and works  will be procured according to ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). All civil works will be procured  through 
international competitive bidding. All consulting firms will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) using quality- and 
cost-based selection, with a quality–cost ratio of 80:20. The CGPWD has prepared the bid 
documents for the first four works contracts and the supervision consultant for the project as 
part of advance procurement action.  
 
34.  Anticorruption. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained 
to  and  discussed  with  the  government,  the  GOC,  and  the  CGPWD.  The  specific  policy 
requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 7). 
D.  Poverty and Social 
35.  Chhattisgarh state has a population of 20,833,803, out of which 16,648,056 persons live 
in rural areas, based on the 2001 census. The state has a population density of 151 per km2 
                                                
11 Economic and Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

8 
and almost 31.8% of the total population of the state is tribal. Chhattisgarh has a high incidence 
of poverty in the country—40.9% of people live below the poverty line.12 
 
36.  The poverty and social assessment surveyed about 25,000 households and men and 
women participated in focus group discussions. The majority stated that the project will increase 
economic and employment opportunities by improving linkages to markets, production centers, 
and public and social service facilities. 
 
37.  Gender.  Focus  group  discussions  were  undertaken  with  women  from  different 
socioeconomic groups in the project influence area. Women stated that the project will benefit 
them; better roads will promote better transport services and give everyone better access to 
social  services,  markets,  workplaces,  higher  education,  health  facilities,  and  employment 
opportunities. 
 
38.  The same effects are expected to be attained under this project for both men and 
women.  The  bidding  documents  provide  clauses  designed  to  ensure  that  all  civil  works 
contractors  comply  with  applicable  labor  laws;  do  not  employ  child  labor;  encourage  the 
employment of the poor, particularly women; and do not offer different wages to men and 
women, particularly for work of equal value. 
 
39.  HIV and AIDS. India’s National AIDS Control Organisation estimates the number of 
persons living with HIV in India at 2.31 million in 2007, and adult HIV prevalence at 0.34%. 
According to India’s National AIDS Control Organisation, HIV infection is typically concentrated 
among the poor and marginalized groups (including such high-risk groups as sex workers, drug 
users, migrant laborers, and truck drivers). These groups, particularly truckers, propel the HIV 
epidemic, and studies indicate that the infection is spreading rapidly to the general population. 
But Chhattisgarh is a low-prevalence state. Based on the poverty and social assessment, there 
is no risk that the project will increase HIV/AIDS incidence. Contractors will carry out HIV/AIDS 
awareness  for  their  laborers  at  work  sites  and  this  will  be  monitored  by  the  construction 
supervision consultants during project implementation. 
E.  Safeguards 
40.  Environmental impact. The project is classified category B for environmental impact in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  The  two  sample  subprojects 
include  rehabilitation  of  existing  roads  within  the  right-of-way  for  most  of  their  length.  No 
protected areas, environmentally sensitive habitats, or reserved forests exist in or near the 
project area. Therefore, the project is unlikely to cause any significant, adverse, or irreversible 
environmental impacts. Initial environmental examination (IEE) reports, including environmental 
management plans (EMP), have been prepared for each subproject. Anticipated impacts, which 
are mainly confined to the construction stage, include generation of dust, noise, exhaust, wastes, 
impacts on water quantity and quality, soil erosion and siltation, tree removal, and occupational 
health  and  safety  issues.  These  impacts  will  be  addressed  through  mitigation  measures 
provided in the EMP, which will be included in the agreement with the contractor. Extensive 
public consultations have been conducted while preparing the IEE, and a grievance redress 
mechanism has also been prepared. An  environmental assessment and review framework 
(EARF) has been prepared to guide environment safeguards-related preparatory work for the 
non-sample subprojects and to ensure compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and 
                                                
12  Government of India, Ministry of Home Affairs, Office of Registrar General & Census Commissioner. 2002. Census 
of India 2001. New Delhi.

9 
the environmental policies of the Government of India. According to the EARF, the non-sample 
subprojects will follow a similar approach for project preparation and implementation as the 
sample subprojects. The EARF as well as the IEE reports for the sample subprojects have been 
endorsed by the executing agency and disclosed on the ADB website as required by ADB’s 
Public Communications Policy (2011). 
 
41.  Land acquisition and resettlement impact. The project is classified category A for 
resettlement impacts. Resettlement plans have been prepared for the two sample subprojects. 
A resettlement framework has been prepared for the project. For all the subsequent subprojects 
that have resettlement impacts, resettlement plans will be prepared in accordance with the 
safeguard provisions in the resettlement framework. 
 
42.  The project was developed with a view to avoiding or minimizing land acquisition and 
involuntary resettlement by adopting the most feasible technical design. The proposed widening 
of roads will occur within the existing right-of-way. A full census was conducted, based on the 
detailed designs for the two sample subprojects. Resettlement plans were prepared for the two 
sample subprojects according to the government’s National Rehabilitation and Resettlement 
Policy (2007), the state resettlement policy, and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. According 
to the census carried out for the two sample subprojects, 1,013 persons will be displaced, out of 
which four households will be physically displaced and 143 economically displaced. The total 
resettlement budget for the sample subprojects is Rs14,961,691. Compensation rates for the 
loss of land and structures, shifting assistance, income restoration assistance, and additional 
support for vulnerable groups are provided in the resettlement framework and resettlement 
plans.  Meaningful  consultation  and  information  disclosure  were  undertaken  during  the 
preparation of resettlement plans, including with (i) project-displaced persons, and (ii) the public 
through  the  ADB  website.  If  any  changes  or  additional  land  requirements  or  involuntary 
resettlement impacts are identified during implementation, a related resettlement plan will be 
prepared or modified according to the applicable laws referred to in the resettlement plan. 
ADB’s prior approval will be obtained before further implementation of the relevant section of the 
subproject. 
 
43.  Impact on indigenous people. The project is classified category B in accordance with 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. Scheduled tribes account for 31.8% of the total population 
in Chhattisgarh. The tribal population is scattered—not concentrated in any particular sample 
subproject areas—and interacts freely with the outside community. The study undertaken for 
preparation  of  the  sample  subprojects  did  not  show  any  difference  in  impact  between 
indigenous  and  non-indigenous  groups  in  the  project  locations.  The  poverty  and  social 
assessment survey confirmed that the socioeconomic impacts of the project will not differ 
significantly  for  tribal  groups  compared  with  the  remainder  of  the  population.  In  addition, 
meaningful consultations were conducted with both primary and secondary stakeholders to 
obtain a comprehensive perspective on the project and its impacts, and to obtain an estimate of 
losses they would suffer and to develop ways to mitigate those losses. Special provisions have 
been  made  under  the  resettlement  plans  to  address  impacts  on  indigenous  peoples.  An 
indigenous  peoples  planning  framework  has  been  prepared  to  address  any  unanticipated 
impacts on indigenous peoples during the implementation of existing or additional subprojects. If 
any significant impacts on indigenous peoples are identified, an indigenous peoples plan will be 
prepared in accordance with the indigenous peoples planning framework and submitted to ADB 
for approval.

10 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
44.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.13  
 
Table 4: Summary Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Initial delays in  CGPWD prepared the detailed design for the roads well in advance. Advance actions 
project  for procurement and ADB support ensure high project readiness. CGPWD staff has 
implementation  been trained in safeguard and procurement requirements to mitigate the potential risk 
of initial delays resulting from procedural clearance. ADB has provided support for due 
diligence for all project roads. 
 
Implementation  The proposed capacity development TA will support the project implementation unit in 
capacity   strengthening the capacity for project management and project implementation. 
 
Insufficient road  The government of Chhattisgarh’s initiatives to improve road asset management and 
asset  planning of preventive road maintenance in CGPWD, through an improved road asset 
management  management system, will be supported by the capacity development TA.

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
VII.  ASSURANCES 
45.  The government, the GOC, and CGPWD have assured ADB that implementation of the 
project shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption 
measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as 
described in detail in the PAM and loan documents. 
 
46.  In addition to the standard assurances, the government, the GOC, and CGPWD have 
given assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents. 
 
VIII.  RECOMMENDATION 
47.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$300,000,000 to India for the Chhattisgarh State Road Sector Project, from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank 
offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 25 years, including a grace period of 
5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board.
